document.docAuthor: Parra-Velandia, Fernando J., Zea, Sven & Van Soest, Rob W. M.
document.masterDocTitle: Reef sponges of the genus Agelas (Porifera: Demospongiae) from the Greater Caribbean

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Reef sponges of the genus Agelas (Porifera: Demospongiae) from the Greater Caribbean

figureCitation.captionText: FIGURE 8. Photographs of Agelas tubulata. Note the position of oscules with respect to the growing axis plane. A) Holotype at ZMA. B) Jamaica. C) H. Lehnert image from ZMA photographic archives. D) Jamaica. E) Solitary tube, Belize; note the little tube bud at the lower left. F) Detail of the previous specimen. G) Robust tubes with irregular grooves at San AndrÃ©s Island, Colombia; note the even surface between grooves. H) Slender group of long tubes at San Andres Island; note predation marks.

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology from Latin, meaning little trumpet shape.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Description. This species forms single tubes or clusters, fused along their sides (
Fig 8
B), some thin-walled and long ( 8 C, 8 H), some stout and robust (
Fig 8
G), arising from a common, generally narrow base (
Fig 8
E); when branching, they usually do so from the base of another tube, and branching is usually not repeated. The whole specimen is 40â60 cm in diameter; each tube can be 20â40 cm high and 3â6 cm in diameter. External colour is orange yellow to reddish or pinskish light brown; internal colour is orange yellow to orange. Surface even, microrugose; pinacoderm rests on tracts of spicules.

Robust specimens can have irregular grooves that may penetrate deep inside the tube wall (
Fig 8
G); there are no oscules on the external surface. Pseudatria 2 to 4 cm in diameter, with a collar-like membrane; oscules ( 5â15 mm ) scattered in the internal wall of the atrium. Consistency of the sponge is elastic, hard to tear and cut. Very hard when dry. The choanosome is dense with narrow channels (< 6 mm ).

Skeleton with primary fibres cored ( 0â5 spicules per cross section) and echinated, 60â120 Îm in diameter; secondary fibres echinated, 40â90 Âµm in diameter. Tertiary fibres are not evident. The acanthostyles are straight with whorls of 5â8 spines; length 84â198 ( 114 Â± 23.7 ) Âµm, width 4â11 ( 6 Â± 1.5 ) Âµm and 11â24 ( 15 Â± 3 ) whorls per spicule. Detailed lengths, widths and average number of whorls are shown in
Table 2
.

Remarks. In Belize and Jamaica the
A. tubulata
tubes tend to be smooth and long; in San Andres and Rosario Islands they tend to be robust and somewhat grooved. Orange brown to orange-yellow long tubes were early recognized as a species of
Agelas
, related to but different from
A. conifera
(see
Colin 1978
and
Zea 1987
). However, intermediate morphotypes also led to the confusion of these two species (e.g.,
Zea 1987
;
GÃ³mez 2002
;
Collin et al . 2005
).

In a closer view, characteristics like colour, pinacoderm, skeleton arrangement and spicule architecture, this species is similar to
A. cerebrum
(
Fig. 14
),
A. conifera
and
A. sceptrum
, which are indeed related species according to molecular phylogeny (
Parra-Velandia, 2011
). Indeed, Dr. P.M. Alcolado ( pers comm ., and see
Alcolado 2002
) considers
A. conifera
,
A. tubulata
and
A. cerebrum
variations of the same species (see remarks under
A. conifera
). We decided to maintain them as separate species until further study.
A. tubulata
differs from
A. cerebrum
(
Fig. 14
) in the general shape (
A. tubulata
tubes vs.
A. cerebrum
barrel/vase-like thickened tubes), smooth and even surface in
A. tubulata
vs. thoroughly grooved and uneven in
A. cerebrum
(robust tubes of
A. tubulata
have grooves, but they are scattered as seen in
Fig. 12
G). Compared to
A. conifera
, the differences are the body size/cone-tube length relation, higher in
A. conifera ,
lower in
A. tubulata
(for more details see remarks under
A. conifera
).
A. sceptrum
differs from
A. tubulata
in the presence of tubes in the latter and its complete absence in the former.

Following this model, a photograph presented in
GÃ³mez ( 2002 : 74 , as
A. conifera
)
clearly shows this species.
Zea ( 1987 )
mentioned two specimens from Old Providence (N of San AndrÃ©s Island) referred by Klaus RÃ¼tzler to this species when it was still undescribed.
Agelas
sp. 1 (specimen not seen) as described by
Pulitzer-Finali ( 1986 )
could belong to
A. tubulata
. A comparison of specimens should solve the issue.

With respect to colour, the underwater photographs of the holotype show a yellow colour and the description states orange-yellow. In the Bahamas , Belize and Jamaica the colour is amber to yellowish, darker in San Andres Islands and continental South America .
